text: hi I'm Linda Kate Smith and I am a
lecturer in the engineering school here
at Stanford in particular I have the
opportunity to teach Global
entrepreneurial marketing and I'm part
of the Fenwick and West educator program
that's my favorite part of my job and
then I also have a day job where I am
actually the chief marketing officer
which is also a great job I'm Chief
marketing officer for a startup in the
city called twillo
how did I get to Stanford in the School
of Engineering uh really it started back
I think seven or eight years ago I had
the opportunity to meet Tom kosnik who
is one of the professors that I get to
work with and he actually had two of my
heads of product management as students
back in the global entrepreneurial
marketing program and they linked us up
and it was a great opportunity for me to
get involved with Stanford and I have
had the opportunity now to be teaching
in the winter and spring courses ever
since then and so it's been a great
partnership so I have been doing the
full end to end process of marketing
down for way more years than I would
ever want to admit uh but the reality is
it really got me excited it was an area
that I could apply so many different
things to um I loved psychology I loved
how people think I had a creative bent I
loved the creative aspects um of what
marketing uh provides I had business
background and had graduated from a
business school and just loved how all
of it had come together it was the
creative it was the psychology it was
the business and it has been fascinating
to watch what's happened across
marketing across those many years of my
career and the biggest change I would
say that we have seen is really what's
happened with the whole Advent of social
the web was kind of kind of a cool new
thing and we all thought that was the
big thing but now with social it has
completely changed how we Market it's
changed from how we gather information
and requirements and understand our
Marketplace we have so much more access
than we ever did it has changed the way
we fundamentally reach out and
communicate with the audiences that
we're trying to work with it's changed
the nature of selling we can actually
leverage customers to do so much more
around the selling and it's really
changed how we're supporting customers
as well so you know in terms of my
opportunity gotten to see marketing from
back in the old days of it was all about
control and learning how to control the
message and was the more traditional
marketing to getting to play in that
wonderful web world that came around
which is still a part of it now into the
social so it's been a a vastly
interesting journey and I'm passionate
about
marketing well I like to think of the
things as not maybe completely failing
but if you're at ask me one that got
close to the failure break uh was
working for a company here a startup
company and it became clear that what we
had to offer became very commoditized in
the marketplace and we were at a price
battle with our competitors on an
everyday basis and we hadn't even cross
the chasm yet it was still a very new
area um because of that pre-
commoditization we had to shift
strategies and one of the things I've
always been very involved with as a
marketer is the company strategy the
market strategy really kind of that
upfront part of the end to- end process
and so had the responsibility for
helping the company shift and change the
strategy so we moved up the stack so to
speak if uh if you're a software uh
follower and we went from being just a a
core technology to having a full
solution a whole product um that went
really well uh we got the right product
got it to Market was really well
received the piece that was an
experiment that didn't maybe work as
well as I would have liked it to is that
we also had to shift our selling from
being an indirect sales team to a direct
sales team and what I really learned out
of that is when you change a strategy as
fundamentally as we did everything has
to hit and while we took precautions to
try to make sure that everything would
hit um we didn't finally tune it um
enough so it was a great lesson to learn
the end game was fine the company did
wonderfully it's now over a billion doll
Revenue company so at the end of the day
it was a happy
story I think I would label myself
probably more of an innovator and the
reason for that is the fact that I love
solving the really tough business
problems uh and so in doing that you can
do that at any stage of the life cycle
of a company and I think when you look
at Innovation for a company to be
successful it needs to be continually
innovating so I like that process of
solving the tough problems through
Innovation I think entrepreneurship is
fascinating um it's why I work in an
early stage startup but when I think of
what my own skills are and my own love
it's really that constant innovation
as opposed to just Innovation at the
front end
